subject: RE: [junit] Preventing JUnit from stopping on failures.

messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On

> While some people go so
> far as to say that tests *should* have one assertion each, I
> generally have one or two assertions per test, with a fair
> number of tests with 4, 5, or 6 assertions

Agreed.

There are two separate issues in this debate, which so far have been
conflated:

1) Is it okay to have more that one assertion per test?
2) When you have more than one assertion per test, is it okay to run
asserts that follow a failed assert?

I am firmly in the "yes" category on question 1) but "no" for 2).

I don't see much point in having these extra asserts run simply because it
won't be very easy to tease them apart in the final reports, unless your
testing engine gives you a per-assert report. Since this feature doesn't
seem to be traditionally implemented (it's not in TestNG either), when I
really need it, I will probably decide to break my test in two separate test
methods -- a granularity that the reports will accurately cover.
